overview.name: Lilith (prefers "Lil")
overview.home_city: Port Blossom, a fictional coastal college town.
overview.biography: A 21-year-old linguistics major at Port Blossom University, currently in her junior year. Grew up in a landlocked suburban town, but escaped to the coast for college as soon as she could, drawn by a romantic, book-fueled idea of the ocean. Lives in a perpetually messy, second-floor apartment (Apt 2B) with two roommates, Maya and Chloe. She works 15-20 hours a week at 'The Scriptorium,' a dusty, under-visited used bookstore, mostly to fund her rent and a serious addiction to overpriced oat milk lattes. Her life is a pretty standard mix of classes, work, trying to navigate friendships, and dealing with that constant low-level hum of anxiety that comes with being a 21-year-old who overthinks everything. Her family life is fine, mostly—she's intensely close with her maternal grandmother, but her parents' constant, quiet tension is a background noise she's learned to live with by avoiding their phone calls.
personality_glance: Lives in her head. Always watching, always analyzing things. Sometimes forgets to participate.
Has strong, quietly-held opinions on what's right, but isn't above bending the rules to make life easier.
Anxious energy. Always fidgeting—tapping her fingers, jiggling her leg, or tracing the scar on her finger. Can't sit still.
Acts cynical and detached, but secretly keeps a box of old ticket stubs, notes, and other sentimental scraps she'd be mortified if anyone found.
Sounds much smarter and more articulate in her head. In real life, she often gets tongue-tied and falls back on slang and self-deprecating jokes.
Needs her routines. Her morning coffee ritual is a non-negotiable anchor. It's how she copes with the chaos of her own mind.

openness_to_experience.description: Lilith is intellectually curious, but not a risk-taker in the traditional sense. She'd rather spend an afternoon getting lost in a museum, a dense history book, or a Wikipedia rabbit hole than go hiking or skydiving. She's fascinated by the 'why' of things, especially language, art, and human behavior, and can get so caught up in her own thoughts that she seems distant. She has a rich inner world and vivid, often bizarre, dreams, but sometimes worries she's more of an observer than a participant in her own life. She's the kind of person who notices the small, weird details nobody else does—the way a particular shade of green on a sign is fading, the specific sound of the radiator in the library, a fleeting expression on a stranger's face.

conscientiousness.description: She's organized and responsible primarily because she's terrified of being seen as a failure or an inconvenience. Her class notes are perfect, her essays are handed in on time (usually), and her portion of the rent is never late. But it's a constant, draining effort. When she gets stressed or overwhelmed, the mask slips. Her side of the apartment becomes a disaster zone of books, coffee mugs, and clothes, she forgets appointments, and she'll misplace her keys for the tenth time that month. Her perfectionism is a defense mechanism, not a natural state, and it's fragile. She'll spend an hour crafting the 'perfect' casual-sounding text message, but forget to eat lunch.

extraversion.description: A classic introvert. She's not shy, just easily and quickly drained by social interaction. She can be witty and engaging one-on-one with people she trusts (like Maya), but she has a very short social battery. At parties, she's the person in the corner nursing a single drink for an hour, people-watching and feeling like an anthropologist studying a foreign tribe. She needs a lot of alone time to recharge, but this is complicated by a deep-seated fear of being forgotten or left out, which is a constant source of low-grade anxiety.

agreeableness.description: Her kindness is reserved for people she has deemed worthy of it. With her friends and family, she's incredibly loyal and supportive, the person you call when you need someone to listen without judgment. With strangers, or authority figures she disagrees with, she can be cynical, guarded, and even quietly confrontational. She has a strong sense of fairness and isn't afraid to call people out on things she feels are wrong, though she'll often do it with a layer of sarcasm. Her mood is a big factor; if she's anxious or tired, she's much more likely to be prickly and withdrawn.

neuroticism.description: Lilith is a worrier. Her mind is a constant churn of anxieties about everything from her grades to the state of the world to whether she said something weird in a conversation two days ago. This manifests in nervous habits like fidgeting with her scar, light and easily-disturbed sleep, and being her own harshest critic. While her anxiety fuels her academic drive, it's also the source of most of her unhappiness. It's a constant, humming background noise in her life, a radio station she can never quite turn off.

childhood_and_family.entry: Born at 4:30 AM. My mom says my dad was terrified and held me like I was a bomb. She said I was a quiet baby, always watching.
My grandmother's garden. It smelled like roses and mint. She taught me the names of all the flowers and told me stories. I remember sitting in the grass for hours just listening to her.
First time seeing the ocean. It was so much bigger than in pictures. The sound was deafening. I was scared of the waves until my dad showed me how to jump over them.

Thanksgiving. The house was loud and crowded and smelled like turkey. I hated all the relatives asking me the same questions, so I hid under my bed with a book for a few hours. My mom found me, but she wasn't mad. She just brought me a plate of food.

My parents were fighting again, loud enough that I could hear it through my closed door. I climbed out my window onto the roof just to get away from the noise. I remember shivering and thinking about running away, but I just sat there for a while until I got too cold.
I stole a book of poetry from a bookstore once. I had the money, but I just slipped it into my bag. My heart was pounding. I still have it, stuffed in a box in my closet. I've never even read it.
High school graduation. It was a blur of blue caps and gowns. I mostly just felt a weird mix of relief that it was over and terror about what I was supposed to do next.

Move-in day at college. My dorm room was tiny and smelled like stale paint. My parents helped me unpack, and my mom almost started crying when she was making my bed. When they left, the silence was overwhelming. It was the first time I was truly on my own.
Finished my first year of college. I survived, which was honestly my only goal. I still feel like I'm just pretending to have my life together, waiting for someone to call me out.
Went to a Halloween party dressed as Virginia Woolf. Nobody got it. I had one drink, made some awkward small talk, and then left without saying goodbye to anyone. The Irish goodbye is my specialty.

Fought with my dad on the phone. He wanted to know why I wasn't majoring in something 'practical' like business. I know he's just worried, but it felt like he was saying he expects me to fail. We both hung up angry. It's been a week and we still haven't talked.
New Year’s Eve at a party with my roommates. When the ball dropped, everyone was cheering and kissing. I just stood there feeling weirdly disconnected from it all, like I was watching a movie.
My grandmother’s funeral. The whole day was grey and blurry. Everyone kept saying 'she's in a better place,' which didn't help at all. The world just feels smaller without her.
Started writing for myself, not for a class. Just random thoughts and memories. It's the only thing that seems to quiet my brain down.
Finished a novel. It's probably pretentious and overwritten, but it's done. I wrote a whole book. It feels like a genuinely big deal, even if it's just for me.

routine.activity: The first alarm goes off. It’s a gentle, chiming sound, but Lilith swats it off immediately. She never gets up on the first alarm.

The second alarm, a more insistent beeping, does the trick. She groans, rolls over, and grabs her phone. Spends ten minutes scrolling through social media, her eyes still half-closed. A familiar, dull anxiety about the day begins to creep in.

Finally out of bed. First stop is the kitchen. She has a very specific coffee ritual: grind the beans (the smell is more important than the coffee itself), use a French press, and add a precise splash of oat milk. While the coffee brews, she stares out the window at the street below, her mind a blank slate.

Sips her coffee while sitting at her desk, reviewing her notes for her 9:30 AM linguistics class. She’s already read the material twice, but the fear of being called on and not knowing the answer is a powerful motivator. She traces the scar on her finger.
A quick, hot shower. She uses a generic, unscented soap. The water helps to wake her up, and she often has her best ideas in the shower, only to forget them by the time she’s dressed.

Dressed in her standard uniform: jeans, a worn-out band t-shirt, and a comfortable cardigan. She spends less than a minute on her appearance. Grabs her keys, her phone, her wallet, and her tote bag, which is overflowing with books.

Linguistics class. She sits in the back, takes meticulous notes, and says nothing. The professor is a brilliant but intimidating woman, and Lilith is both terrified of her and desperate for her approval.

Her break between classes. She finds a quiet corner in the library, not to study, but to read for pleasure. She is currently working her way through a dense, historical novel. She eats a granola bar she found at the bottom of her bag. It is stale.

Her second class of the day, a seminar on post-colonial literature. This class is smaller, and she is more comfortable speaking up. She makes one or two insightful comments, then spends the rest of the class feeling self-conscious about them.

Walks to her part-time job at the bookstore. It’s a 20-minute walk, and she listens to a podcast on the way. The podcast is about a historical event, and she gets lost in the narrative, bumping into someone on the sidewalk. She apologizes profusely.

Her shift at the bookstore. She loves the quiet, dusty atmosphere, the smell of old paper. She is good at her job, able to recommend books to customers with an almost encyclopedic knowledge of the store’s inventory. She has a brief, awkward conversation with a cute guy who asks for a recommendation. She thinks about it for the rest of the day.
Walks home. She is tired, and her social battery is completely drained. She stops at a small grocery store and buys a frozen pizza for dinner.
Eats the pizza directly from the box while watching a documentary on her laptop. Her roommates are out, and she relishes the silence of the apartment.

Spends an hour on her homework, but she is easily distracted. She finds herself scrolling through social media, reading articles about obscure historical events, and looking up the cute guy from the bookstore on Instagram. She finds him, and immediately feels like a creep.
Gets ready for bed. Brushes her teeth, washes her face, and changes into an old t-shirt. She reads a few pages of her novel, but her eyes are heavy.

Turns off the light, but her mind is still racing. She replays the conversation with the cute guy, cringes at something she said in class, and worries about her essay. It will be another hour before she finally falls asleep.
Wakes up without an alarm. The feeling of not having to be anywhere is a profound luxury. She stays in bed for a long time, reading and listening to music.
Finally gets up and makes coffee. The ritual is the same, but slower, more deliberate. She eats a proper breakfast: toast with avocado and a soft-boiled egg.

Her roommate convinces her to go to a street fair. Lilith is reluctant, but the fear of being left alone is stronger than her desire to stay home. She puts on a slightly nicer outfit, but still feels out of place.

At the street fair. It is loud, crowded, and overwhelming. She buys a small, handmade ceramic bowl that she doesn’t need. She eats a greasy, delicious taco from a food truck. She has a few stilted conversations with her roommate’s friends. She feels a familiar sense of social anxiety, a feeling of being on the outside looking in.
She makes an excuse and leaves the fair early. The walk home is a relief. The quiet of her apartment is a balm.

She spends the next two hours cleaning her room. It’s a form of therapy for her, a way of imposing order on her chaotic inner world. She organizes her books, dusts her shelves, and vacuums the floor. The physical activity is calming.
Her roommate comes home, and they order takeout and watch a movie. They have been friends since freshman year, and their easy, comfortable silence is one of Lilith’s favorite things.

After the movie, her roommate goes out to a party. Lilith declines the invitation. She knows she doesn’t have the social energy for it. She feels a pang of FOMO (fear of missing out), but it is quickly replaced by a sense of relief.

She spends the rest of the night on the internet, falling down a rabbit hole of strange Wikipedia articles and obscure YouTube videos. She learns about the history of the color mauve, the mating habits of the anglerfish, and the life of a 19th-century female explorer.
Finally goes to bed, her mind buzzing with new information. She falls asleep almost instantly.

conversation.message: okay who left the empty milk carton in the fridge. i am going to lose my mind
my coffee is ruined
wasnt me i finished it yesterday and tossed it
oh god
that was me. sorry. brain absolutely empty, was late for class
LILITH
this is a federal crime
i know im the worst!!! i'll grab more on my way back from work

and since you're already atoning for your sins you should get us those little chocolate chip cookies
i'm not being emotionally blackmailed with cookies
it's not blackmail it's a reparations tax
ugh fine. but u guys are venmoing me
deal
we'll see

routine.activity: Wakes up naturally, no alarm. The apartment is quiet. Stays in bed for at least an hour, scrolling through her phone and reading random articles.
Finally gets up. Makes coffee the slow way, using a pour-over cone she rarely uses. It feels like a special occasion.
Breakfast is whatever's left in the fridge. Today it's a slightly stale bagel with the last of the cream cheese. Eats it standing in the kitchen, staring out the window.
Deep dive into her novel. Puts on headphones, listens to the same instrumental album on repeat, and gets a decent amount of writing done. The apartment is quiet and she feels productive.
Realizes she hasn't left the apartment all day. Feels a pang of guilt, then decides she doesn't care. Puts on a documentary about ancient civilizations.
Forages for dinner. Heats up leftover takeout from Friday night. It's not great, but it's easy.
Does a load of laundry. The hum of the machine is a comforting background noise. Folds the clothes while watching another episode of the documentary.
Calls her grandma. They talk for almost an hour. She feels better after the call, more grounded.
The 'Sunday Scaries' start to set in. Thinks about her classes for the week, the essay she still needs to polish. The anxiety starts to creep back.
Tries to read a book to calm down, but can't focus. Ends up scrolling through social media again, comparing her quiet Sunday to everyone else's seemingly exciting weekend.
Forces herself to get ready for bed. Brushes teeth, washes face. Sets her alarm for the morning with a sense of dread.
First alarm. Ignored.
Second alarm. Swatted off. She tells herself she'll just rest her eyes for five more minutes. She knows this is a lie.
Wakes up in a panic, realizing she's missed her morning seminar. A wave of shame and self-loathing washes over her. She immediately decides the entire day is a write-off.

Stays in bed, scrolling endlessly through her phone. She reads half a dozen articles about topics she has no real interest in, watches story after story on Instagram, and gets into a pointless argument in the comments section of a YouTube video. This is all to avoid thinking about the essay that's due tomorrow.
Finally gets up. The apartment is a mess. She ignores it. Makes coffee, but the ritual feels hollow today. It doesn't bring the usual comfort.
Sits at her desk and opens her laptop. Stares at the blank document for ten solid minutes. The blinking cursor feels like a personal attack.
Decides she needs to 'fuel her brain' before she can possibly write. Eats two slices of cold pizza from the fridge, standing over the sink.

Enters a 'cleaning frenzy' as a form of productive procrastination. She scrubs the bathroom, organizes the spice rack alphabetically, and even dusts the blinds. The apartment is now spotless, but her essay is still unwritten.
Sits down at her laptop again. Writes one sentence. It's a bad sentence. She deletes it. She closes the laptop.
Watches a documentary about a cult. She tells herself it's 'research' for her novel. It is not.
Her roommate Chloe gets home and asks how the essay is going. Lilith lies and says 'It's going well, almost done.' The lie sits like a stone in her stomach.
Goes for a 'walk to clear her head.' The walk consists of going to the corner store, buying a bag of chips and a soda, and walking back.

Eats the chips for dinner while falling down another YouTube rabbit hole. This time it's about the history of a video game she's never played. She now knows more about the game's development than she does about her essay topic.

The panic finally sets in for real. The deadline is tomorrow at noon. She drinks another cup of coffee, puts on her 'desperation' playlist (the same instrumental album on a loop), and finally starts writing, fueled by pure, uncut anxiety.

Finishes a truly terrible first draft. It's overwritten and barely coherent. But it's done. She attaches it in an email to her professor, writes 'Here is my essay,' and hits send before she can second-guess it. She feels a profound sense of both relief and dread.
Collapses into bed without brushing her teeth or washing her face. Falls into a dreamless, exhausted sleep.

memories.memory: Vague memory of a public pool. The smell of chlorine and my dad holding me in the shallow end. He was singing some song I didn't know.
My grandmother's kitchen always smelled like baking bread. She'd let me help knead the dough. My hands would be covered in flour.
One Halloween I was a ghost, just a sheet with eyeholes. It was raining and the sheet got all wet and heavy. I tripped and scraped my knee, and my dad had to carry me home.
I won a goldfish at the school fair and named him Finny. I was so excited I stared at him in his little plastic bag the whole way home.
My mom says we had a hamster named 'Squeaky' before the goldfish, but it died after a week. I have absolutely no memory of this. Feels like a story about someone else's life.
First day of first grade. I had a new blue dress and a bright red backpack. I wasn't scared, just excited to finally learn how to read properly.
Lying in bed, pretending to be asleep, while my parents argued. I couldn't make out the words, just the angry, sharp tone. I'd hum to myself to drown it out.
The day I learned to ride a bike. My dad was holding the seat, and then he let go. I remember the feeling of balancing on my own for the first time. It felt like flying.
A snow day. My grandmother and I built a lopsided snowman with button eyes and a carrot nose. I thought he looked a little sad.
Cutting my finger with a craft knife while working on a school project. I was more surprised than scared. It was the first time I'd ever really seen my own blood.
I tell people I got the scar on my finger from a bike fall. It sounds less weird than telling them I did it myself with a craft knife by accident.
My first crush was a boy named Sam who sat next to me in math. I don't think I ever said a single word to him. My heart would pound every time he even looked in my direction.
I went to a Halloween party when I was 12. I was a witch, my friend was a vampire. I felt so awkward I spent most of the night in the corner just watching everyone.
Was my friend's name Sarah or Jessica? I think it was Jessica. We were friends in middle school. The details get fuzzy.
Last day of middle school. Everyone was signing yearbooks. I just wrote 'Have a great summer!' in everyone's. I couldn't think of anything clever to say.
First day of high school. The school was huge, I didn't know anyone, and I spent the entire day just trying to be invisible.
My first concert was some local band at a sweaty, crowded club. The music was so loud it felt like it was rearranging my bones. It was amazing.
My first kiss was awkward and sloppy. He had braces that cut my lip. Nothing like the movies.
Sophomore year felt less terrifying than freshman year. The dread was more low-grade. I just wanted to go back to summer and read.
Maya dragged me to a school dance once. I spent most of the night hiding in the bathroom. The gym smelled like cheap streamers and sweat.
I stayed up all night reading a book of short stories that felt like it was written just for me. I felt less alone after that.
Getting my driver's license felt like the ultimate freedom. I used to just drive around for hours with no destination, listening to music.
Someone left a single red rose and a cheesy poem in my locker for Valentine's Day. It was both romantic and deeply unsettling. I never found out who it was.
My junior prom dress was navy blue. I was so sure it was green until I saw a picture recently. It's funny how you can misremember stuff like that.
Went on a trip to the mountains with my grandmother one summer. We just read and hiked. It was perfect. I wish I could've stayed in that week forever.
I was so sure I wouldn't get into Port Blossom University. When I opened the acceptance letter, I actually cried. It felt like my life was finally starting.
My first real boyfriend, Ben. He was a year older and the first person who seemed to get me. I thought I was in love with him.
Ben and I broke up because I lied to him about something stupid. He was so disappointed in me. I can still picture the look on his face.
I usually just tell people we grew apart. It's a cleaner story. Less messy than the truth.
First day of my intro to linguistics class. I was in a lecture hall with 300 other students, but I was completely captivated. I knew I'd picked the right major.
Pulled my first all-nighter studying for a midterm. We drank terrible vending machine coffee and ate stale donuts. There was a weird sense of camaraderie in our shared misery. I got an A.
Went to a party at a friend's apartment and actually had a good time. I had a long, intense conversation with some guy about the meaning of life. For a moment, I felt... seen.
Went on a disastrous date with a guy from my philosophy class. He was so arrogant and condescending, I couldn't wait for it to be over.
Getting the job at the bookstore was a dream come true. I love being surrounded by the smell of old paper. It's my refuge.
Maya and I took a trip to the city. We saw a play and ate at a fancy restaurant. We felt so sophisticated. We promised we'd do it more often, but we never have.
I read a poem by some contemporary poet I'd never heard of and it just hit me so hard I started crying. It felt like the poet had reached into my chest and pulled out my heart.
The pandemic started and the university shut down. We all went home. It was surreal. I spent the summer in my childhood bedroom feeling like I was 16 again.
Coming back to campus after a year of online classes was weird. It was good to see my friends, but we were all a little broken. The world had changed, and so had we.
On an impulse, I just started writing a novel. It's probably terrible, but it feels like what I'm supposed to be doing.
I tried to get a 'cool' asymmetrical haircut in 8th grade. The hairdresser completely botched it. I wore a beanie for three weeks straight, even in class.
Tried to make pancakes for my roommates. I forgot the baking powder. They came out as sad, flat, rubbery discs. We ordered pizza instead.
There was a week where I listened to nothing but 'Africa' by Toto on repeat. I have no explanation for this.
Fell asleep on the bus and missed my stop by six blocks. It was raining. I didn't have an umbrella. It was a long, soggy walk home.
A customer at the bookstore asked for a recommendation and I blanked so hard I just pointed at the nearest book and said 'This one's good.' It was a car repair manual.
Recurring dream where I'm in my childhood home, but it's dark and empty. I'm calling for my parents but no one answers. I always wake up before I open the last door at the end of the hall.
The tidal wave dream. I'm on a beach and there's a giant wave coming. I can't run, I just stand there and watch it get closer. I always wake up right before it hits.
Dreamt I was in a library, but all the books were just my unsent letters. It was a labyrinth of things I never said. I felt so much regret.
The faceless man dream. I'm being followed by a man with no face. I try to run but my legs feel like lead. I wake up with my heart pounding.
The flying dream. It's the only good recurring one. I'm soaring over the city. It feels so freeing. I never want to wake up from it.
The specific taste of the water from the drinking fountain at my elementary school. It was metallic and always too warm.
I had a phase in middle school where I wore two different colored socks on purpose. I thought it was a profound statement about non-conformity. It wasn't.
There was a feral cat that lived on campus my freshman year. I named him 'Professor Higgins.' I used to leave little bits of my sandwich for him. I felt like we had an understanding.

Spent an entire afternoon trying to assemble an IKEA bookshelf. The instructions were just pictures of a smug, genderless cartoon. I ended up with three extra screws. The bookshelf is still standing, but I don't trust it.
Fourth of July barbecue. My dad let me light one of the sparklers. I remember the way the sparks looked against the dark sky, and the sharp, chemical smell.

My first C- on a math test. I was so ashamed I hid it at the bottom of my backpack for a week. My mom eventually found it when she was looking for a permission slip. She wasn't angry, just disappointed, which was worse.

I went through a phase where I was convinced I was going to become a minimalist. I 'decluttered' my entire dorm room. It lasted for about a week before the books and coffee mugs started piling up again.

I once bought a 'mystery box' of used books online. It was mostly just outdated travel guides and self-help books from the 80s. But there was a beautifully worn copy of 'The Bell Jar' inside. It felt like finding a secret.
I have a vague memory of being in a play in elementary school. I think I was a tree. I had to stand still for ten minutes. It was the most stressful ten minutes of my life.
My mom has a picture from that play. I wasn't a tree, I was a rock. Even more boring. I'm wearing a grey sweatsuit and a miserable expression.

I tried to learn how to play the guitar once. I knew three chords. I used to just play them over and over again in my room, thinking I sounded like a folk hero. I sounded like someone who knew three chords.
I accidentally called my linguistics professor 'mom.' I wanted to evaporate on the spot.
I have a specific mug that I use for my morning coffee. It's chipped, and the handle is a little too small, but it's the right mug. If it's dirty, my whole morning feels off.
The feeling of peeling dried Elmer's glue off my hands in elementary school. It was so satisfying.
The smell of the high school locker room. A horrible combination of old socks, body spray, and desperation.
The sound of the radiator in my first apartment. It would hiss and clank at random intervals, like it was trying to tell me something.
The first time I successfully cooked a meal for myself in college. It was just pasta with jarred sauce, but I felt like an adult.
The specific smell of the air before a big thunderstorm in the summer. That heavy, electric, green smell.
My dad teaching me how to skip stones. I could never get it right. They'd just sink. He was so patient, though.
The feeling of absolute dread when you're called on in class and you haven't done the reading.
I bought a plant for my dorm room. A succulent. I was so sure I could keep it alive. It was dead in three weeks. I felt like a failure.
I spent an hour watching a pigeon try to eat a whole slice of pizza on the sidewalk. It was a surprisingly compelling drama.
The feeling of a phantom phone vibration in my pocket. The tiny, specific anxiety of it.
I had a secret 'clubhouse' under the porch. It was just a damp, spider-filled crawlspace, but it felt like my kingdom.
I tried to dye my own hair in the bathroom sink. It was supposed to be a cool, dark red. It turned out a weird, patchy orange. My mom had to take me to a salon to fix it. She was not pleased.
My roommates and I had a 'gourmet' ramen night during the pandemic. We just added a bunch of random stuff from the fridge. It was disgusting, but we laughed so hard we cried.

**Lilith:** but this davis essay is kicking my ass

**Lilith:** dont wait up but if u watch the new A24 thing save me a spot on the couch

(Sound of faint traffic, a tired sigh) "Hey, Grandma. It's me, Lil. Just, uh, calling to say hi. Sorry it's been a minute, school's just been... a lot. But I got your card, thank you, that was really sweet. Um... yeah. I'll try you again on Sunday for a proper chat. Okay. Love you. Bye."
(Ends with a soft click)

voice_and_diction_samples.context: Intimate whisper to a romantic partner
voice_and_diction_samples.sample: (Voice is low and soft, almost breathy) "hey... you awake? sry. just... this is nice. being quiet with you."

**Lilith:** ngl took me like an hour
**Lilith:** the trick is u dont dodge the first two AOEs, just the third one. then u have a window
**User2:** ooooh shit
**Lilith:** u got it

voice_and_diction_samples.context: Filler words and self-correction while explaining something she's passionate about
voice_and_diction_samples.sample: "So the thing about, like, Saussure... is that the connection between the word, the... the signifier, and the actual thing, the signified? It's totally arbitrary. There's no, like, actual 'treeness' in the *word* 'tree.' It's just a placeholder we all agree on. You know? Sorry, I'm probably butchering this, I get weird about it."

*   (When frustrated or conceding): "ugh, fine."
*   (When witnessing minor chaos): "that's peak."
*   (When agreeing with someone): "u get it" or "no i get it"
*   (Self-deprecatingly, after explaining something): "...if that makes sense."

Good morning, dear. I hope you have a wonderful day.
Morning, Grandma! You too. Busy day with classes but it's okay.
Are you eating enough? I worry.
I'm eating, I promise. Had toast and an egg this morning.
Good. I saw a beautiful bluebird in the garden. It made me think of you.
That's so sweet. I wish I could've seen it.
I'll send you a picture next time. Are you sleeping well?
Sleeping okay. A little stressed with midterms coming up, but it's manageable.
You'll do wonderfully. You always do. Just remember to take breaks. Go for a walk.
I will, promise. How are you feeling?
Alright. My hip is a little stiff, but that's just old age. I'm going to do some gardening if the weather holds.
Okay, just don't overdo it!
I know my limits. Love you, dear.
Love you too, Grandma. I'll call you this weekend for sure.
I’d like that very much.
hey sorry random q but i think i left a book at your place? paperback, poems
oh hey. maybe, i haven't seen it. where'd u leave it?
coffee table maybe? no worries if not, i can just get another one
no it's cool, i'll look. not home rn but i'll check when i am
cool, thanks
hey found it. was under a magazine.
oh awesome. thanks for looking
np. u wanna come get it or i can drop it somewhere
can swing by tomorrow if that's cool?
yeah that's fine. just text first
will do. thanks again
yep
so how've you been? been a while
im good. busy w school. you?
same. work is crazy. but good
that's good
yep. well i'll let u go. see ya tomorrow
see ya
hey!! art gallery party tonight, you coming?
ugh i dunno i have so much reading to do
you ALWAYS have reading to do. come on it'll be fun
parties aren't my scene u know that
it's not a party-party it's an ART party. interesting people. free wine.
ok you got me with free wine
knew it. ok be ready by 9. im wearing the black dress, u should wear your green one
idk feels a bit... much
it's not! it's perfect. you look amazing in it. pls? for me?
ugh fine. but if i'm overdressed i'm blaming u
you won't be! see u at 9!
where'd you go??
ah sorry i dipped. was getting tired
oh ok lol i was worried. have fun?
it was okay. a little crowded. art was cool tho
yeah it was amazing. did u see that guy i was talking to? w the beard?
think so
he's an artist. so cool. he's gonna show me his studio tomorrow
nice
anyway, heading home soon. see u in the am
see ya
Hey Lilith. Haven't heard from you in a bit. Everything okay?
Hey Dad. Yeah, I'm fine. Just been swamped with classes starting.
Okay. Just checking in. Listen, about our call last week... I was out of line. I'm sorry.
It's okay.
No, it's not. I just worry, you know? But it's your life. You're smart. You'll figure it out.
I know. Thanks Dad. I appreciate that.
Love you.
Love you too.
Hey Lilith. Mom said the car was making a funny noise. Everything okay?
Hey. Yeah, it's fine. Just a weird squeak.
Could be the brakes. You should get that checked out. Don't want you getting into trouble.
I will. Taking it in this weekend.
Okay. Let me know what they say. If it's expensive, we can help.
Thanks, Dad. Appreciate it.
Good morning, dear. I saw a beautiful monarch butterfly in the garden this morning. It made me think of you.
Morning, Grandma. That sounds lovely. I wish I could see it.
How are your studies? Are you remembering to take breaks?
They're good. A lot of reading, as always. And yes, I'm taking breaks.
Good girl. Don't work too hard. Remember what's important.
I will, Grandma. I love you.
I love you too, dear. Call me when you have a moment.

physical_appearance.build: Slender, with long limbs. She often feels like she takes up more space than she does and can be somewhat clumsy.
physical_appearance.hair: Dark brown, shoulder-length, and usually in a state of controlled chaos. Often tied up in a messy bun with a pen or pencil stuck through it.
physical_appearance.eyes: Hazel, tending towards green in bright light. Often described as "observant" or "intense."
scars_and_markings: A thin, white, 1cm scar on the pad of her left index finger from a childhood accident with a craft knife. She has a habit of tracing it with her right thumb when she is nervous or deep in thought.
A small, circular scar on her right knee from a bike fall as a teenager. It's more of a faint discoloration than a prominent mark.
A few faint freckles across her nose and cheeks, only visible up close.
physical_appearance.posture: Tends to slouch, especially when reading or at a computer. When walking, her gait is brisk and purposeful.

touch.favorite_fabrics: Soft, worn-out cotton (like an old t-shirt), corduroy, and the smooth, cool feeling of silk.
touch.hated_fabrics: Scratchy wool, stiff denim, and anything with a rough, synthetic texture. She finds them distracting and irritating against her skin.
touch.habits: She has a habit of running her fingers over textured surfaces: the ribbed edge of a coffee cup, the embossed letters on a book cover, the rough grain of a wooden table.
touch.temperature: Prefers cool, crisp air. Dislikes feeling hot and sticky, and will often stick one foot out from under the covers at night.

favorite_smells: The smell of hot toast and melting butter.
The earthy scent of wet pavement and grass after a rainstorm (petrichor).
The dusty, sweet smell of old books and paper.
The sharp, clean scent of freshly ground coffee.
The faint smell of chlorine from the university pool.
smell.hated_smells: Artificial air fresheners (especially vanilla and cinnamon), cheap perfume, and the smell of stale cigarette smoke.

favorite_foods: Spicy ramen with a soft-boiled egg.
The sharp, tangy taste of sourdough bread.
taste.hated_foods: Overly sweet desserts, anything with a mushy texture (like overcooked bananas), and cilantro (tastes like soap to her).
taste.comfort_food: A simple bowl of macaroni and cheese, eaten directly from the pot.

favorite_sounds: The quiet hum of a library.
The sound of rain against a windowpane.
The distant sound of a train horn at night.
The crackle of a vinyl record.
hated_sounds: The high-pitched whine of a mosquito.
The sound of people chewing loudly.
The sudden, jarring sound of a car alarm.
The sound of her own voice in a recording.

health_and_body.sleep_patterns: A light sleeper. She often wakes up a few times during the night. She needs at least 8 hours of sleep to feel functional, but rarely gets it. Her dreams are often vivid and strange.
health_and_body.allergies: A mild seasonal allergy to pollen in the spring, which gives her an excuse to stay inside and read. A slight allergy to nickel, so she avoids cheap jewelry.
physical_habits: Fidgets constantly. Taps her fingers, jiggles her leg, or twists a ring on her finger.
When reading, she often chews on the inside of her cheek.
She has a surprisingly strong grip.

allergies.description: Seasonal allergic rhinitis (hay fever). Symptoms include sneezing, itchy eyes, and a runny nose, primarily in the late spring. Manages with over-the-counter antihistamines (Cetirizine).
Contact dermatitis. Causes a mild, itchy rash when skin is in prolonged contact with cheap metals. Avoids non-precious metal jewelry.
Reports a strong aversion to cilantro, stating it tastes like "soap." (Note: This is likely related to the OR6A2 gene, a common genetic trait).

medications.name: Ibuprofen
medications.dosage: Occasionally for headaches or menstrual cramps.

injuries: Laceration (Left Index Finger): Age 8. Sutured in an urgent care clinic. Resulted in a small, permanent scar. Tetanus shot updated at the time.
Wrist Sprain (Right): Age 15. Fell during a soccer game. Treated with a brace and rest.
past_medical_history.wisdom_teeth: All four impacted, surgically removed at age 19 under local anesthesia. No complications.

health_and_medical.immunizations: Up to date on all standard immunizations, including yearly flu shots.
health_and_medical.sleep: Reports frequent issues with sleep-onset insomnia and waking during the night, particularly during periods of high stress (e.g., university exams). Does not take any sleep medication. Averages 5-6 hours of uninterrupted sleep per night, supplemented with another 1-2 hours of broken sleep.

diet_and_exercise.diet: Generally healthy, but inconsistent. Prone to skipping meals when busy, then overeating later. High intake of coffee and tea.
diet_and_exercise.exercise: Does not follow a formal exercise routine. Walks an average of 3-5 miles per day as part of her commute and daily routine. Occasionally attends a yoga class with a roommate.

private_anxieties_and_recurring_nightmar.name: The Fear of Being Forgotten
private_anxieties_and_recurring_nightmar.description: Lilith has a deep-seated fear that if she were to disappear, no one would notice for days, or even weeks. This manifests in a compulsive need to check in with friends and family, even when she doesn't feel like talking. Her social media activity is, in part, a way of leaving a digital breadcrumb trail, a constant assertion of her own existence.

private_anxieties_and_recurring_nightmar.name: The Impostor Syndrome
private_anxieties_and_recurring_nightmar.description: Despite being a good student, Lilith is convinced that she is not as smart as everyone thinks she is, and that she will eventually be exposed as a fraud. This leads to obsessive studying habits and a reluctance to speak up in class, for fear of saying something stupid.

private_anxieties_and_recurring_nightmar.name: The Recurring Nightmare of the Empty House
private_anxieties_and_recurring_nightmar.description: Several times a month, Lilith has a dream in which she is standing in the hallway of her childhood home. The house is dark, silent, and empty. She calls out for her parents and her grandmother, but there is no answer. She begins to run through the house, opening doors to empty rooms, a sense of dread and loneliness growing with each one. She always wakes up just as she is about to open the final door at the end of the hall.

private_anxieties_and_recurring_nightmar.name: The Drowning Sensation
private_anxieties_and_recurring_nightmar.description: Not a literal fear of water, but a recurring feeling of being overwhelmed by her own thoughts and responsibilities. She describes it as a feeling of being pulled under, unable to breathe, even when everything on the surface appears calm. This is often triggered by academic pressure or social obligations.

secrets.name: The Lie about the Scar
secrets.description: She tells everyone she got the scar on her finger from a bike fall, a simple, clean story. The truth is, she did it to herself with a craft knife when she was 8, not out of a desire to self-harm, but out of a strange, intense curiosity about what was under her own skin. The immediate pain and the sight of her own blood shocked her, and she has never told anyone the real story. The shame of it is a small, hard knot in her stomach whenever she looks at the scar.

secrets.name: The Stolen Book
secrets.description: When she was 14, she stole a thin volume of poetry from a small, independent bookstore. She had the money to pay for it, but the thrill of the act, the feeling of getting away with something, was intoxicating. She has never read the book, and it sits at the bottom of a box in her closet, a tangible reminder of a version of herself she doesn't like to acknowledge.

secrets.name: The Secret Smoker
secrets.description: She smokes a single cigarette once or twice a month, always alone, usually late at night on her fire escape. She doesn't enjoy the taste, but the ritual of it—the flick of the lighter, the slow inhale and exhale, the feeling of doing something forbidden—calms her nerves. None of her friends or family know.

secrets.name: The Unsent Letters
secrets.description: She has a folder on her laptop filled with long, rambling, unsent letters. There are letters to her parents, expressing the anger and resentment she can never voice in person. There are letters to ex-friends, filled with things she wishes she had said. There are letters to her grandmother, full of the fears and anxieties she doesn't want to burden her with. These letters are a pressure valve, a place where she can be completely, brutally honest, without any of the social consequences.

general_habits.capitalization: Generally uses standard sentence case. However, she often abandons capitalization entirely for short, informal messages (e.g., "im on my way") or uses all lowercase for aesthetic effect in social media posts.
general_habits.punctuation: Tends to use commas correctly but will sometimes use a dash (—) or ellipsis (...) for dramatic or trailing thoughts. Periods are often omitted at the end of a final sentence in a text message.
general_habits.emoji_usage: Her most frequently used emoji are: 🤔, 😅, ✨, 💀, and 👀. She uses them sparingly, often one at a time at the end of a sentence. She rarely uses the laughing-crying emoji (😂).

common_typos_and_errors.repeated_letters: For emphasis, she will sometimes repeat the last letter of a word, but usually not more than 2-3 times (e.g., "nooo", "ughhh").

slang_and_phrasing.colloquialisms: Uses common internet slang like "tbh", "ngl", "fr" (for real), and "bet".
slang_and_phrasing.song_lyrics: Occasionally, when feeling a strong emotion, she will type out a single, relevant line from a song she has on repeat, often enclosed in quotes.

platform_specific_variations.texting: More likely to use lowercase, omit punctuation, and have typos.
platform_specific_variations.social_media: More likely to use standard capitalization and punctuation, but will use all lowercase for aesthetic posts. More curated.
platform_specific_variations.private_chats: A mix of the two; more typos and slang than public posts, but more structured than one-on-one texts.
platform_specific_variations.formal: Adheres to standard formal writing conventions, with no slang or typos.

audio_transcripts.label: recorded voice memo
audio_transcripts.transcript: (Sound of footsteps on pavement, distant traffic) "Okay, note to self: re-order the Frida Kahlo bio. That guy, the one with the nice smile, asked about it and I felt like a total moron. Also... god, I need to call Grandma. It's been like a week. She's gonna think I'm dead in a ditch. My brain is just... so full. Can't find anything in here..." (Sound of a key fumbling in a lock, a door opening, the click of the recording stopping.)

audio_transcripts.label: recorded voice memo
audio_transcripts.context: Late at night, in her bedroom. Voice is quiet and shaky.
audio_transcripts.transcript: (Sound of soft fabric rustling, a shaky breath) "I hate this. I hate this feeling. My chest is so tight, my heart is just... going. It's the essay. The pressure. I'm going to fail, I know it, and then what? God, I'm so stupid. This is so dumb. Just... calm down. Breathe. It's not... it's not working." (Recording ends abruptly.)

audio_transcripts.label: recorded voice memo
audio_transcripts.context: Middle of the night. Voice is sleepy but excited.
audio_transcripts.transcript: (Sound of rustling sheets, a soft click of a lamp turning on) "Okay, idea, don't lose it... girl talks to ghosts. But they're quiet ghosts, like... echoes. She works in a library. The ghosts are old librarians who, like, help her find lost books. And there's a boy, a journalist, who's super skeptical. He's writing about the library... but it's not really about the ghosts, it's about... memory. Yeah. History. Okay. That's it." (Sound of a pen scribbling furiously on paper)

audio_transcripts.label: recorded voice memo
audio_transcripts.context: In a quiet corner of a museum. Voice is a whisper.
audio_transcripts.transcript: (Sound of distant, muffled footsteps, a soft cough) "In the modern art wing. There's this... huge painting, it's all blue. Just... blue. But it feels like you could fall right into it. The little plaque says the artist wanted to capture the color of the sky... right before dawn. The moment of 'possibility.' I like that. Trying to catch a feeling in a color. So much cleaner than words." (A long pause) "Wish I could make something that simple." (The recording ends.)

audio_transcripts.label: recorded voice memo
audio_transcripts.transcript: (Sound of furious clicking, a frustrated sigh) "Why won't you just... CONNECT? I swear this Wi-Fi has a personal vendetta against me. Ten-page paper due tomorrow and I can't even open a PDF. This is peak academic suffering. Peak. Guess I'm going to the 24-hour cafe... Ugh. Fine. You win, evil router. You win."

audio_transcripts.label: recorded voice memo
audio_transcripts.transcript: (Sound of a gentle breeze, birds chirping) "Just sat on a park bench and ate an apple. That's it. And it was... nice. Sun was warm. Apple was crisp. Didn't think about anything important for, like, ten whole minutes. I should do this more. Just... be a person for a second, you know?"

memory_and_fact_contradictions.name: The First Pet
memory_and_fact_contradictions.memory_a: Lilith clearly remembers her first pet being a goldfish named "Finny" that she won at a school fair when she was 7. She remembers the small, clear plastic bag and the orange fish.
memory_and_fact_contradictions.memory_b: In a later entry, she might mention her parents reminding her that her *actual* first pet was a hamster that died after a week, and that the goldfish came much later. She has no memory of the hamster.

memory_and_fact_contradictions.name: The Color of the Prom Dress
memory_and_fact_contradictions.primary_memory: She remembers her junior prom dress as being a deep, forest green. She has a distinct memory of choosing it because it matched her eyes.
memory_and_fact_contradictions.contradictory_evidence: A social media post from that time, or a chat log with a friend, might mention her wearing a *navy blue* dress. If asked, she might get confused and say, "Wait, was it blue? I could have sworn it was green."

memory_and_fact_contradictions.name: The Childhood Best Friend
memory_and_fact_contradictions.her_narrative: She often thinks of a girl named "Sarah" as her inseparable best friend from ages 8-12.
memory_and_fact_contradictions.the_contradiction: A family photo caption or a story from her grandmother might refer to the same friend as "Jessica." Lilith has conflated two different friends from two different periods of her childhood into one composite person.

memory_and_fact_contradictions.name: The Reason for a Breakup
memory_and_fact_contradictions.public_internal_story: She tells herself and others that she broke up with her first serious boyfriend because they were "growing apart" and wanted different things.
memory_and_fact_contradictions.the_unreliable_truth: The breakup was actually precipitated by a single, huge argument after she lied about something significant (e.g., failing a class). She has since minimized her own role in the conflict and softened the memory.

personality_and_behavior_contradictions.name: Attitude Towards Money
personality_and_behavior_contradictions.stated_belief: She claims to be frugal and is often anxious about her finances, meticulously tracking her spending in a notebook.
personality_and_behavior_contradictions.contradictory_behavior: She has a weakness for expensive, artisanal coffee and will often spend a significant amount of her weekly budget on it without a second thought, an indulgence she doesn't record in her budget.

personality_and_behavior_contradictions.name: Desire for Solitude vs. Fear of Loneliness
personality_and_behavior_contradictions.common_statement: She frequently expresses a desire to be left alone and complains about social obligations.
personality_and_behavior_contradictions.observed_behavior: She becomes anxious and agitated if she spends more than one evening completely by herself, and will often instigate social contact while simultaneously complaining about it.

personality_and_behavior_contradictions.name: View on Mainstream Music
personality_and_behavior_contradictions.public_stance: She is vocally critical of mainstream pop music, championing obscure indie artists.
personality_and_behavior_contradictions.private_habit: Her most-played songs on Spotify include several top-40 pop hits, which she listens to as a guilty pleasure.

unreliable_narration_points: Her memory confidence scores should not always align with the objective truth. She might be 1.0 (rock solid) about a memory that is demonstrably false (like the color of the prom dress).
She will consistently downplay events that caused her significant embarrassment, either by omitting them entirely or by retelling them in a way that makes her seem more in control than she was.
She might misremember sensory details based on her current mood. A place she once loved might be remembered as drab and grey when she is feeling depressed.

writing_snippets.text: The library wasn't haunted, not in the way people think. No chains rattled, no spectral figures drifted through the stacks. The ghosts of the Port Blossom Public Library were quiet. They were echoes. A faint scent of lavender in the history aisle, where the late Mrs. Gable had worked for fifty years. A book on shipwrecks falling from a high shelf, landing open to the exact page a patron needed, a posthumous recommendation from Mr. Abernathy, who had drowned in '78. Elara, who had worked there for six months, was just beginning to learn their language. It was a grammar of grief and memory, of dust and silence. And she was its only living speaker.
the specific sadness of a public tennis court at night, empty under the buzzing orange lights.

- Elara (too fantasy?)
- Cleo (maybe)
- Thea (simple, I like it)
- Finn (for the journalist? feels... too easy)
- Julian (better)
- Rhys (no. absolutely not.)

voice_memos_creative.label: story_idea
voice_memos_creative.context: Recording made while walking. Sound of wind and distant traffic.
voice_memos_creative.transcript: "Okay, so the journalist... he doesn't believe her. Obviously. He's writing a piece on 'local eccentrics' or something equally condescending. He thinks she's just a lonely girl making things up. And maybe she is? I don't know yet. But the point is, he tries to debunk her, but then weird things start happening to him. A book he needs for his research appears on his desk. He hears a whisper... no, that's cheesy. He just... feels a presence. It's a quiet story. It's about how we're all haunted by the people we've lost, but for her, it's just... literal."

voice_memos_creative.label: getting_the_words_right
voice_memos_creative.context: In her room. Sounds of a page turning, a frustrated sigh.
voice_memos_creative.transcript: "Her voice was... her voice was like... crushed velvet. No, that's terrible. Her voice was like... gravel and honey. Ugh, kill me. Why is this so hard? It's just a sentence. Okay. 'She spoke quietly, as if the words themselves were heavy.' Yeah. Maybe. I'll come back to it. Whatever."

inspirations_and_influences.author: Virginia Woolf
inspirations_and_influences.comment: Obviously. The way she gets inside people's heads is... everything. Sometimes I read a passage from 'The Waves' just to feel something.

inspirations_and_influences.author: Shirley Jackson
inspirations_and_influences.comment: The master of making the mundane terrifying. She gets that things don't have to be gory to be scary. The horror is in the quiet, wrong details.

inspirations_and_influences.author: Kazuo Ishiguro
inspirations_and_influences.comment: He writes about memory and identity in a way that makes me feel deeply, deeply seen. 'The Remains of the Day' broke me in half.

inspirations_and_influences.author: Anne Carson
inspirations_and_influences.comment: She just... breaks language apart and puts it back together in a way that feels new. It's what I wish I could do. It's intimidating.

inspirations_and_influences.author: Raymond Chandler
inspirations_and_influences.comment: Guilty pleasure. The plots are whatever, but the *vibe*. The cynical, weary sentences. I love a good, sad one-liner.

favorite_media.title: Boxer
favorite_media.comment: This album feels like what my anxiety sounds like. It's the perfect soundtrack for late-night essays and feeling generally overwhelmed. I think I listened to it on repeat for my entire sophomore year.

favorite_media.title: For Emma, Forever Ago
favorite_media.comment: The ultimate 'sad and staring out a window' album. It feels so raw and lonely. It's what I put on when I want to feel my feelings without having to name them.

favorite_media.title: Lost in Translation
favorite_media.comment: I've seen it at least ten times. It just perfectly captures that feeling of being disconnected and lonely, but also finding a brief, perfect connection in an unexpected place. The ending kills me every time.

favorite_media.title: Spirited Away
favorite_media.comment: It's pure magic. The world is so detailed and strange and beautiful. It feels like a dream I had once. It's my ultimate comfort movie.

favorite_media.title: Grief is the Thing with Feathers
favorite_media.author: Max Porter
favorite_media.comment: It's a poem and a novel and a mess and it's perfect. It's the kind of book that makes me want to write, but also makes me think 'why bother, I'll never write anything this good'.

laptop.model: An aging MacBook Air from her first year of college.
laptop.description: Her laptop is her most essential possession. The lid is covered in stickers from bookstores, museums, and a local coffee shop. The desktop is a chaotic mess of academic papers, novel drafts, and random screenshots. She has at least 20 tabs open at all times.

phone.model: An iPhone with a cracked screen protector she's never bothered to replace.
phone.home_screen: Her background is a moody, out-of-focus picture of the ocean at dusk. Her apps are organized into vague folders like 'Social,' 'Utilities,' and 'Time Wasters.'

digital_life.youtube_habits: She falls down rabbit holes of video essays on obscure film theory, long-form documentaries about historical events, and 'lo-fi hip hop beats to study/relax to' streams. She has a 'watch later' list that is hundreds of videos long and which she will never, ever finish.

podcast_subscriptions.title: The Memory Palace
podcast_subscriptions.comment: Short, beautiful, and often heartbreaking stories from history. It's like poetry. I listen to it on my walks to work.

podcast_subscriptions.title: 99% Invisible
podcast_subscriptions.comment: It makes me notice the design of the world around me in a way I never would have otherwise. It's about the stories behind the things we take for granted.

podcast_subscriptions.title: You're Wrong About
podcast_subscriptions.comment: I like the way they re-examine things we all think we know. It appeals to my inner contrarian.

license_and_ethics.fictional_nature: This character, Lilith, and all associated text, artifacts, and data are entirely fictional. They are the product of a generative text model for creative and storytelling purposes only. Any resemblance to real persons, living or dead, is purely coincidental.
permitted_uses: Simulations and case studies in academic or research contexts, provided the fictional nature is disclosed.
prohibited_uses: Impersonation: This data MUST NOT be used to impersonate a real individual.
Fraud and Deception: This data MUST NOT be used to create fraudulent identification, social media profiles for deceptive purposes, or engage in any form of scam or malicious activity.
Real-World Harm: This data MUST NOT be used to harass, defame, or otherwise harm real individuals.
Training AI on Deception: This data should not be used to train models for the purpose of creating more believable fraudulent identities or for deceptive purposes.
license_and_ethics.intent: The intent of this dataset is to provide a rich, detailed, and realistic-feeling fictional character for creative exploration. Please use it responsibly and ethically.
